clusters.title: Salesforce says it won’t pay extortion demand in 1 billion records breach
clusters.neutral_headline: Salesforce Refuses Extortion Payment After Data Breach

items.title: Salesforce says it won’t pay extortion demand in 1 billion records breach

ai_summary: Salesforce confirmed a breach involving one billion records, but will not pay the extortion demand.
The company is investigating the incident and working with law enforcement agencies.
The attackers demanded payment to prevent the release of the stolen data.
Salesforce has not disclosed the specific type of data compromised in the breach.
The company is notifying affected customers and providing support services.

clusters.title: Logitech will brick its $100 Pop smart home buttons on October 15
clusters.neutral_headline: Logitech to Disable Pop Smart Home Buttons in October

items.title: Logitech will brick its $100 Pop smart home buttons on October 15

ai_summary: Logitech will discontinue support for its Pop smart home buttons on October 15.
The buttons will become non-functional after the support end date.
Users will no longer be able to control smart home devices with the buttons.
Logitech cited the need to focus on other product lines as the reason.
Customers are being offered a discount on other Logitech smart home products.

clusters.title: Vandals deface ads for AI necklaces that listen to all your conversations
clusters.neutral_headline: Vandals Damage Advertisements for AI-Powered Necklaces

items.title: Vandals deface ads for AI necklaces that listen to all your conversations

ai_summary: Advertisements promoting AI necklaces were vandalized by unknown individuals.
The necklaces are designed to record and analyze all surrounding conversations.
The vandals targeted the ads with graffiti and other forms of defacement.
The AI necklaces have raised privacy concerns among some consumers.
The company is assessing the damage and considering its response to the vandalism.

clusters.title: Synology caves, walks back some drive restrictions on upcoming NAS models
clusters.neutral_headline: Synology Reverses Drive Restrictions on New NAS Models

items.title: Synology caves, walks back some drive restrictions on upcoming NAS models

ai_summary: Synology has altered its plans for drive restrictions on upcoming NAS models.
The company initially planned to limit drive compatibility to specific models.
User feedback prompted Synology to reconsider the initial restrictions.
The revised policy allows for broader compatibility with various hard drives.
Synology will provide more details on the changes in the near future.
